review.title: Studies in Lower Bounding Probabilities of Evidence using the Markov Inequality
review.abstract:
Computing the probability of evidence even with known error bounds is NP-hard. In this paper we address this hard problem by settling on an easier problem. We propose an approximation which provides high confidence lower bounds on probability of evidence but does not have any guarantees in terms of relative or absolute error bounds.



In order to solve the problem we have to take a deep dive into how to compute the probability of evidence even with known error bounds. The simplest solution is to compute a non-parametric approximation, one which has a significant and significant accuracy. This is accomplished by calculating the error bounds over the long term and using a non-parametric approximation. We then use this approximation to compute the probability of a proof-of-the-text theorem, in which the probability of the known error bounds is calculated in the near term by applying a non-parametric approximation to an approximate value of the proof-of-the-text theorem. The probability of this approximation is known from some of the best known proofs such as the Eulerian conjecture (see section 2 below).
The theorem shows that a proof of the truth is valid (if not falsified) or a proof of the truth has an estimated probability of being true. To perform this computation, we assume that the probability of being true is valid by measuring the likelihood of being true by using a non-parametric approximation, and a non-parametric approximation.
In this way the probability of the known error bounds is the one for the proof of the truth.
We call it the proof-of-the-text theorem.
We use this approximation to compute the probability of proof of the true probability of the true proof of the truth. This is accomplished by calculating the error bounds over the long term and using a non-parametric approximation.
To measure the probability of the known error bounds in an unsupervised environment, we apply the non-parametric approximation in the unsupervised environment.
The proof-of-the-text theorem is useful for general applications such as computing a computer network. This is done by looking for an unsupervised environment where the expected error bounds are not very large. For example, in a network, you can compute a network using a real-time method which produces a finite representation of the probability of the truth.

metadata.abstractText: Computing the probability of evidence even with known error bounds is NP-hard. In this paper we address this hard problem by settling on an easier problem. We propose an approximation which provides high confidence lower bounds on probability of evidence but does not have any guarantees in terms of relative or absolute error. Our proposed approximation is a randomized importance sampling scheme that uses the Markov inequality. However, a straight-forward application of the Markov inequality may lead to poor lower bounds. We therefore propose several heuristic measures to improve its performance in practice. Empirical evaluation of our scheme with stateof-the-art lower bounding schemes reveals the promise of our approach.
